transfer
balanceOf
transferFrom
approve
allowance

nodes.documentation:
approve should be called when allowed[_spender] == 0. To increment
allowed value is better to use this function to avoid 2 calls (and wait until
the first transaction is mined)
From MonolithDAO Token.sol
nodes.name: increaseApproval

nodes.documentation:
To create the token, compile and deploy RepuX with a multisig wallet address as input argument. The multisig will be used to store Ether
received in the ICO. The wallet address used to deploy the contract will be the owner address of the token contract, and all commands should
be issued from this address. All functions with the onlyOwner modifier in this contract can be only be invoked by the owner address. It is
of absolute importance that the multisig wallet and owner wallet are kept secure in the team's hands.
To change the multisig address, invoke the setMultisig(address addr) function with the new multisig wallet address as input argument.
To change the owner address, use the original owner address to invoke proposeNewOwner(address newOwner) and pass in the candidate
for new owner address as input argument. Then, use the candidate address to invoke acceptOwnerTransfer(). That will conclude the team
transfer process, and the candidate address will become the new owner address. This 2-step transfer process prevents situations where
the team accidentally transfers the contract ownership to the wrong address, resulting in irrevocable damage.
To start the presale, invoke the startPresale() from the owner address. To conclude presale, invoke the concludePresale() function.
If the presale token supply is not sold out, unsold tokens will become available in the crowdsale.
To start the crowdsale, invoke the startCrowdsale() function. startCrowdsale() can only be invoked after the presale is concluded.
To conclude the crowdsale, invoke the concludeCrowdsale() function. It can only be invoked either after the ICO period has ended, or
after crowdsale tokens have sold out.
During both presale & crowdsale, contributors can directly send Ether to the token contract address. Upon receiving Ether, the smart
contract will generate a transaction hash based on the transaction information, store the transaction information, and fire up a
ContributionReceived event containing the transaction hash and information. A server can listen to such events with the web3js API.
It can also query the hashes of all transactions that have occured by calling getContributionHashes(). With a known transaction hash,
a server can query the information of its corresponding transaction by calling getContributionFromHash(bytes32 transactionHash).
After the KYC process, the team/server can either accept a contribution by calling acceptContribution(bytes32 transactionHash), or reject
if by calling rejectContribution(bytes32 transactionHash), both with the transaction hash of the contribution as the input argument. If
a contribution is accepted, the Ether received from this transaction will be transferred to the team multisig wallet, and the tokens will
be sent to the recipient's wallet address. On the other hand, if the contribution is rejected, the Ether will be sent back to the contributor.
After the crowdsale concludes, the lock-up period for token transfer, team tokens and 2nd ICO reserve tokens will begin. Token
transfer will become available ~2 days after the end of crowdsale. After about 12, 24 & 36 months respectively, the team can withdraw
its share of tokens (4% of total supply each withdrawl) by invoking withdrawTeamToken(). After about 2 years, the team can withdraw the
reserve tokens for 2nd ICO by calling ICOReserveWithdraw().
Note that all time intervals, including crowdsale phases and the lock-up periods, are approximated by average blocktime of the Ethereum
blockchain. The default blocktime is set to 30s. The team can adjust the blocktime before start of the crowdsale by invoking
setAverageBlockTime(uint256 newBlockTime), with the new blocktime (in seconds) as input argument.
In case of emergency, the team can halt the presale/crowdsale by calling halt() in order to prevent further damages. After the emergency
is resolved, the team can unhalt the crowdsale by calling unhalt().*
nodes.name: RepuX
